SubTopics: Use place value understanding to round multi-digit whole numbers to any place.
Content: The population of a certain city is 836,527. What is the population of this city rounded to the nearest ten thousand?

SubTopics: Measure angles in whole-number degrees using a protractor. Sketch angles of specified measure.
Content: What is the measure of the angle shown below?
problems/NY17G4M/media/2a.jpg

SubTopics: Understand addition and subtraction of fractions as joining and separating parts referring to the same whole.
Content: Which expression is equivalent to 7/10 – 2/10?

SubTopics: Draw points, lines, line segments, rays, angles (right, acute, obtuse), and perpendicular and parallel lines. Identify these in two-dimensional figures.
Content: Which statement best describes the figure shown below?
problems/NY17G4M/media/4a.jpg

A.Choice: The ray appears to be perpendicular to 2 line segments that appear to be parallel.

B.Choice: The ray appears to be parallel to 2 line segments that appear to be perpendicular.

C.Choice: The line segment appears to be perpendicular to 2 lines that appear to be parallel.

D.Choice: The line segment appears to be parallel to 2 lines that appear to be perpendicular.

SubTopics: Multiply a whole number of up to four digits by a one-digit whole number, and multiply two two-digit numbers, using strategies based on place value and the properties of operations. Illustrate and explain the calculation by using equations, rectangular arrays, and/or area models.
Content: What is the product of 32 × 67?

SubTopics: Explain why a fraction a/b is equivalent to a fraction (n × a)/(n × b) by using visual fraction models, with attention to how the number and size of the parts differ even though the two fractions themselves are the same size. Use this principle to recognize and generate equivalent fractions.
Content: The models below are shaded to represent equivalent fractions.
problems/NY17G4M/media/6a.jpg
Which fraction is equivalent to the fractions shown by the models?

SubTopics: An angle is measured with reference to a circle with its center at the common endpoint of the rays, by considering the fraction of the circular arc between the points where the two rays intersect the circle. An angle that turns through 1/360 of a circle is called a “one-degree angle,” and can be used to measure angles.
Content: What is the measure of an angle that turns through 3/4 of a complete circle?

SubTopics: Make a line plot to display a data set of measurements in fractions of a unit (1/2, 1/4, 1/8). Solve problems involving addition and subtraction of fractions by using information presented in line plots.
Content: Andrew is growing tomato plants in his garden. The line plot below shows the height of each tomato plant on Wednesday.
problems/NY17G4M/media/8a.jpg
What was the difference in height between the tallest plant and the shortest plant?

SubTopics: Apply the area and perimeter formulas for rectangles in real world and mathematical problems.
Content: A square is shown below.
problems/NY17G4M/media/11a.jpg
Kelsey drew a rectangle with the same area as the square. The length of Kelsey's rectangle is 8 inches. What is the perimeter, in inches, of Kelsey's rectangle?

SubTopics: Solve multistep word problems posed with whole numbers and having whole-number answers using the four operations, including problems in which remainders must be interpreted. Represent these problems using equations with a letter standing for the unknown quantity. Assess the reasonableness of answers using mental computation and estimation strategies including rounding.
Content: Some bakers make apple pies.

:box:• They have 15 boxes of apples.

• Each box has 18 apples.

• They use 7 apples for each pie.
What is the total number of apple pies that the bakers can make?

SubTopics: Understand that shapes in different categories (e.g., rhombuses, rectangles, and others) may share attributes (e.g., having four sides), and that the shared attributes can define a larger category (e.g., quadrilaterals). Recognize rhombuses, rectangles, and squares as examples of quadrilaterals, and draw examples of quadrilaterals that do not belong to any of these subcategories.
Content: The shapes that each of 5 students drew are shown below.
problems/NY17G4M/media/15a.jpg
Which list has the names of all the students who drew quadrilaterals?

SubTopics: Recognize angle measure as additive. When an angle is decomposed into non-overlapping parts, the angle measure of the whole is the sum of the angle measures of the parts. Solve addition and subtraction problems to find unknown angles on a diagram in real world and mathematical problems, e.g., by using an equation with a symbol for the unknown angle measure.
Content: Angles STU and UTV combine to form right angle STV.
problems/NY17G4M/media/16a.jpg
Which expression could be used to find the measure, in degrees, of angle UTV?

SubTopics: Explain why a fraction a/b is equivalent to a fraction (n × a)/(n × b) by using visual fraction models, with attention to how the number and size of the parts differ even though the two fractions themselves are the same size. Use this principle to recognize and generate equivalent fractions.
Content: On the number lines shown below, points Y and Z represent fractions that are equivalent to the fraction represented by point X.
problems/NY17G4M/media/17a.jpg
problems/NY17G4M/media/17b.jpg
problems/NY17G4M/media/17c.jpg
Which fractions do points Y and Z represent on the number lines?

A.Choice: Point Y represents 4/6 and point Z represents 8/12.

B.Choice: Point Y represents 4/6 and point Z represents 9/12.

C.Choice: Point Y represents 6/8 and point Z represents 8/12.

D.Choice: Point Y represents 6/8 and point Z represents 9/12.

SubTopics: Recognize angle measure as additive. When an angle is decomposed into non-overlapping parts, the angle measure of the whole is the sum of the angle measures of the parts. Solve addition and subtraction problems to find unknown angles on a diagram in real world and mathematical problems, e.g., by using an equation with a symbol for the unknown angle measure.
Content: In the diagram below, angle ABD measures 153° and angle ABC measures 67°.
problems/NY17G4M/media/21a.jpg
What is the measure of angle CBD?

SubTopics: Find whole-number quotients and remainders with up to four-digit dividends and one-digit divisors, using strategies based on place value, the properties of operations, and/or the relationship between multiplication and division. Illustrate and explain the calculation by using equations, rectangular arrays, and/or area models.
Content: What is the quotient of 1,224 ÷ 9?

SubTopics: Find all factor pairs for a whole number in the range 1–100. Recognize that a whole number is a multiple of each of its factors. Determine whether a given whole number in the range 1–100 is a multiple of a given one-digit number. Determine whether a given whole number in the range 1–100 is prime or composite.
Content: Which number is a multiple of 7?

SubTopics: Make a line plot to display a data set of measurements in fractions of a unit (1/2, 1/4, 1/8). Solve problems involving addition and subtraction of fractions by using information presented in line plots.
Content: For a science project, Joseph recorded the amount of rainfall each day for 2 weeks. The table below shows his data.
problems/NY17G4M/media/24a.jpg
Which line plot correctly displays Joseph's data?

SubTopics: Multiply a whole number of up to four digits by a one-digit whole number, and multiply two two-digit numbers, using strategies based on place value and the properties of operations. Illustrate and explain the calculation by using equations, rectangular arrays, and/or area models.
Content: A student has 3 puzzles. Each puzzle has 1,250 pieces. What is the total number of pieces in the puzzles?

SubTopics: Interpret a multiplication equation as a comparison, e.g., interpret 35 = 5 × 7 as a statement that 35 is 5 times as many as 7 and 7 times as many as 5. Represent verbal statements of multiplicative comparisons as multiplication equations.
Content: A baseball cap costs $8. A matching shirt costs 4 times as much as the cap. Which of the following can be used to determine the cost of the shirt?

SubTopics: Explain why a fraction a/b is equivalent to a fraction (n × a)/(n × b) by using visual fraction models, with attention to how the number and size of the parts differ even though the two fractions themselves are the same size. Use this principle to recognize and generate equivalent fractions.
Content: Which letter on the number line below represents a fraction equivalent to 4/6?
problems/NY17G4M/media/27a.jpg

SubTopics: Solve real world and mathematical problems involving perimeters of polygons, including finding the perimeter given the side lengths, finding an unknown side length, and exhibiting rectangles with the same perimeter and different areas or with the same area and different perimeters.
Content: A rectangular sign is shown.
problems/NY17G4M/media/28a.jpg
What is the perimeter, in feet, of the sign?

SubTopics: Recognize a line of symmetry for a two-dimensional figure as a line across the figure such that the figure can be folded along the line into matching parts. Identify line-symmetric figures and draw lines of symmetry.
Content: Which figure has exactly one line of symmetry?

SubTopics: Find whole-number quotients and remainders with up to four-digit dividends and one-digit divisors, using strategies based on place value, the properties of operations, and/or the relationship between multiplication and division. Illustrate and explain the calculation by using equations, rectangular arrays, and/or area models.
Content: If a total of 762 students at a citywide competition are divided into 6 equal-sized teams, how many students are on each team?

SubTopics: Multiply or divide to solve word problems involving multiplicative comparison, e.g., by using drawings and equations with a symbol for the unknown number to represent the problem, distinguishing multiplicative comparison from additive comparison.
Content: At a neighborhood park, there are 11 spaces for bicycles on a rack by the basketball court. The bicycle rack by the playground has 3 times as many spaces for bicycles as the one by the basketball court. Which equation could be used to find the total number of bicycle spaces on the rack by the playground?

SubTopics: Solve word problems involving multiplication of a fraction by a whole number, e.g., by using visual fraction models and equations to represent the problem.
Content: Melina walked 9/12 mile each day for 5 days. What was the total distance, in miles, she walked in the 5 days?

SubTopics: Compare two fractions with different numerators and different denominators, e.g., by creating common denominators or numerators, or by comparing to a benchmark fraction such as 1/2. Recognize that comparisons are valid only when the two fractions refer to the same whole. Record the results of comparisons with symbols >, =, or <, and justify the conclusions, e.g., by using a visual fraction model.
Content: Rowan has 3 pieces of yarn, as described below.

:box:• a red piece of yarn that is 3/4 foot long

• a yellow piece of yarn that is 6/8 foot long

• a blue piece of yarn that is 4/12 foot long
Which number sentence correctly compares the lengths of 2 of these pieces of yarn?

SubTopics: Draw points, lines, line segments, rays, angles (right, acute, obtuse), and perpendicular and parallel lines. Identify these in two-dimensional figures.
Content: Four angles are shown below.
problems/NY17G4M/media/36a.jpg
How many of these angles are acute?

SubTopics: An angle that turns through n one-degree angles is said to have an angle measure of n degrees.
Content: Each time Rami turned the dial on a machine, the dial moved 1 degree. Rami turned the dial 10 times. What is the total number of degrees the dial moved?

SubTopics: Multiply a whole number of up to four digits by a one-digit whole number, and multiply two two-digit numbers, using strategies based on place value and the properties of operations. Illustrate and explain the calculation by using equations, rectangular arrays, and/or area models.
Content: Which method can be used to solve 11 x 13?

A.Choice: Multiply 11 x 10 and 10 x 3, then add the two products.

B.Choice: Multiply 11 x 10 and 11 x 3, then add the two products.

C.Choice: Multiply 11 x 100 and 10 x 3, then add the two products.

D.Choice: Multiply 11 x 100 and 11 x 3, then add the two products.

SubTopics: Explain why a fraction a/b is equivalent to a fraction (n × a)/(n × b) by using visual fraction models, with attention to how the number and size of the parts differ even though the two fractions themselves are the same size. Use this principle to recognize and generate equivalent fractions.
Content: Which model is shaded to represent a fraction that is equivalent to 9/12?

SubTopics: Find whole-number quotients and remainders with up to four-digit dividends and one-digit divisors, using strategies based on place value, the properties of operations, and/or the relationship between multiplication and division. Illustrate and explain the calculation by using equations, rectangular arrays, and/or area models.
Content: What is 123 ÷ 8?

SubTopics: Add and subtract mixed numbers with like denominators, e.g., by replacing each mixed number with an equivalent fraction, and/or by using properties of operations and the relationship between addition and subtraction.
Content: Becky and James have a total of 4 2/8 feet of yarn. Becky has 15/8 feet of yarn. How many feet of yarn does James have?
